text:
Happy Monday, marketers!

*Question: How are you using webinars in your company?* 
I am working _B2C_ and wondering where where live events/webinars/whatever you want to call them fit in the content mix.
I'm wondering how other content marketers keep their webinars focused:

• What purpose do your webinars serve?
• What are you measuring from them?
• Have they been successful for you? If so, why?
Thank you :the_horns:

text:
I agree my deliverables up front. This may or may not include a meeting. 99 times out of 100, I include an asynchronous video alongside my deck/doc if something isn't clear. All my clients are happy with this :)

If they want more time, they pay for it. And they expect this because my deliverables are very clear on my contract/purchase order.

Never don't charge for your time.

elements.text: I agree my deliverables up front. This may or may not include a meeting. 99 times out of 100, I include an asynchronous video alongside my deck/doc if something isn't clear. All my clients are happy with this :)
If they want more time, they pay for it. And they expect this because my deliverables are very clear on my contract/purchase order.
Never don't charge for your time.

text: We've hosted two webinars at Mio. Attendance rate was good but more views have come from uploading to YouTube and embedding to blog posts.

elements.text: We've hosted two webinars at Mio. Attendance rate was good but more views have come from uploading to YouTube and embedding to blog posts.

text:
When I worked in house we did monthly webinars, sometimes 2x a month. I did work B2B though.

For your site, I think webinars could work really well with educating consumers on what tutoring could look like for them. Getting one of your tutors to do a group lesson or even hosting a webinar on how to select a great language learning tutor.

I think the best webinars are practical and when selling takes a backseat to what everyone is learning. If you pick the right topic learning more about a product or signing up can be a natural next step if someone feels like they got something out of the webinar. You don't want attendees to feel like they joined a giant sales pitch or demo.

text:
Hey everybody, I haven't been active on this community for a while, but this is a Hail Mary moment for me.

My question: *How do you come up with a data-driven content strategy when there's not much search volume for most keywords in your industry?* 

*Background:* I'm a marketing communications writer for a social-service software company, and I'm running point on content strategy for the year. I'm new to the role, but I'm having a hard time coming up with topics to focus our blog/newsletter on, because most of them are low-volume keywords. Now, I still plan on using some longtail keywords to inform what I write about, but at the same time, how do I understand the echochambers and media diet of my audience?

elements.text:
Hey everybody, I haven't been active on this community for a while, but this is a Hail Mary moment for me.

My question:
How do you come up with a data-driven content strategy when there's not much search volume for most keywords in your industry?
Background:

I'm a marketing communications writer for a social-service software company, and I'm running point on content strategy for the year. I'm new to the role, but I'm having a hard time coming up with topics to focus our blog/newsletter on, because most of them are low-volume keywords. Now, I still plan on using some longtail keywords to inform what I write about, but at the same time, how do I understand the echochambers and media diet of my audience?

text:
I was in a fairly similar situation. My biggest piece of advice is to get the data firsthand by talking to people!

1. Interview your customers - ask them what types of things they’re thinking about, problems they solve with your product, etc. That will be a gold mine.
2. Interview your sales team - what customer concerns/questions come up a lot?
3. You can also survey your customers - could be a nice entry point to set up the discussions too (i.e. have a “would you mind if I interview you” question at the end)
I don’t know the whole picture at your company, so take this advice with a grain of salt, but if you have low search volume, it’s more likely that you should be making bottom-funnel content to support sales.

elements.text: I was in a fairly similar situation. My biggest piece of advice is to get the data firsthand by talking to people!
Interview your customers - ask them what types of things they’re thinking about, problems they solve with your product, etc. That will be a gold mine.
Interview your sales team - what customer concerns/questions come up a lot?
You can also survey your customers - could be a nice entry point to set up the discussions too (i.e. have a “would you mind if I interview you” question at the end)

I don’t know the whole picture at your company, so take this advice with a grain of salt, but if you have low search volume, it’s more likely that you should be making bottom-funnel content to support sales.

Pls lmno if I can help with more connects.

text:
Any advice on how to handle working with a client's team when they don't have a full grasp of SEO or how their suggestions/proposed changes could negatively impact their goals for the finished content piece? Working on a blog for a client, and they're wanting to use a bunch of terms that have either little or no ranking potential or are really hard to rank for and aren't relevant to their brand.

They're also not happy with the article length; saying it's too long, but it's just over 2k words.

elements.text:

Working on a blog for a client, and they're wanting to use a bunch of terms that have either little or no ranking potential or are really hard to rank for and aren't relevant to their brand.

They're also not happy with the article length; saying it's too long, but it's just over 2k words.

text: That's a good point, especially the last one. I think that's probably going to be a big thing for me, creating sales-enablement materials, given that the top-of-funnel keywords just aren't there.

elements.text: That's a good point, especially the last one. I think that's probably going to be a big thing for me, creating sales-enablement materials, given that the top-of-funnel keywords just aren't there.

text: Seemingly.

elements.text: Seemingly.

text:
I like to ground my work in the research. Tools like Frase, while they can be used to create bad copycat content, help defend this by showing what entities Google (and humans) expect to see, and gives justification as to why an article is that long.

You can also show them that people don't often read an entire article, but read the opener to see if it's worth skimming for the specific information they want at that moment.

elements.text:

text: Thought leadership content that's highly shareable or differentiates you from competitors is likely going to move the needle more

text: Agree that the best thing for you to do is speak to your customers either through interviews or via a survey. Not only will you get some great insights, but you can actually use both interviews (if you ask permission as part of the interview process) and survey data to create thought leadership content. Original research often generates a lot more engagement than other types of content.

elements.text: Agree that the best thing for you to do is speak to your customers either through interviews or via a survey. Not only will you get some great insights, but you can actually use both interviews (if you ask permission as part of the interview process) and survey data to create thought leadership content. Original research often generates a lot more engagement than other types of content.

text: I’ve been there! Lean on your internal team to understand the biggest questions and pain points for your audience, and write content that addresses them. Those keywords are so important, even if the SEO tools give you a big fat 0 on volume. (In my case, I worked at a vacation rental management company where homeowners looking to rent out their second/third/fourth properties were super important audience. There wasn’t much keyword volume for that niche crowd, but terms like “checklist for stocking a vacation rental” got our content directly in front of our valuable target market.)

<@U01QBQGJREJ> I'm also on the "Talk to customers" team. One time after a round of research interviews for a client, I identified at least 2 dozen topic ideas - mapped along with various points of the buying journey.

Sometimes you can even find low-volume search terms with high intent. Here is the framework I use: <https://www.contentlift.io/my-one-case-study>

text:
The headless CMS? We used it at LeaseFetcher. It's good for complex web applications where you need the presentation layer and business logic decoupled.

Could you talk about what you're building and your requirements? That might help folk give better advice.

text:
I work in a B2C fintech and webinars have been really important for us. We have a weekly webinar series where we interview different guests — after the webinar, we upload the video to our YouTube channel, turn the audio into a podcast, and upload it to our blog. Outside of the weekly series, we use webinars to support any big Marketing campaigns we're running (hosting panel discussions that align with the topic, etc.) or as a channel for any immediate, timely info where we want to give people an opportunity to ask questions via a Q&A.

Totally agree with Amanda's point above. It's primarily a driver for engagement over acquisition.

What does decoupling the presentation layer and business logic look like in practice?
